author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: How We Hug Now
description: We’re still figuring it out.
content: Welcome. Last weekend I went to a party where I reunited with several friends I hadn’t seen since early 2020 or before. I greeted each with The New Hug.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Catch up on Election Day results from around the U.S.
description: The governor’s races in Virginia and New Jersey and the New York City mayoral election are among the highlights.
content: A year after voters elected President Biden and pushed Republicans fully out of power in Washington, the G.O.P. rebounded with a strong election night on Tuesday, highlighted by Glenn Youngkin’s victory in the Virginia governor’s race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Weapons Tracing Study Implicates Russia in Ukraine Conflict
description: One of the most comprehensive studies to date of weaponry in the war in Ukraine shows a panoply of Russian-supplied arms that has helped fuel the war.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — A study of weapons and ammunition used in the war in Ukraine shows that Russia has been systematically fanning the conflict with arms shipments, according to a new report funded by the European Union and the German government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: ‘Dr. Brain,’ Your New South Korean TV Crush
description: In the afterglow of Netflix’s “Squid Game,” Apple TV+ premieres its first Korean-language series, a mind-melding sci-fi mystery.
content: “Dr. Brain” has not received the launch that you might expect for a mini-series made by a significant South Korean filmmaker, one that’s an important building block in Apple TV+’s attempt to upgrade its international content. The show’s Thursday debut was announced less than two weeks ago, and even then, there was confusion about the actual date it would premiere in the United States. The ritual press day with cast and crew, just announced on Tuesday, is taking place a week after the premiere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Eshe Nelson
title: Central banks around the world are dialing back their pandemic-era support.
description: The Federal Reserve, the Bank of England and the Reserve Bank of Australia are among several central banks pulling back support as inflation jumps.
content: Tangled supply chains, rising costs for raw goods and soaring consumer demand have combined to push prices rapidly higher in many wealthy countries, prodding central banks around the world to start dialing back some of the extraordinary economic support measures they put in place during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Eric Adams, Mayor-Elect
description: Adams claimed an overwhelming victory and called for unity: “Today we take off the intramural jersey and we put on one jersey — team New York.”
content: Good morning. Eric Adams, who found a place in New York City’s political consciousness as a reform-minded police officer more than 20 years ago, was elected mayor. And scroll down to meet some deep-sea look-alikes that could scare you — unless you like sharks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Vaccination status and Thanksgiving could be ‘a really combustible mix,’ experts say.
description: Last year, pre-Thanksgiving concerns centered on social distancing and taking risks with the coronavirus. This year, the focus is inoculation; more than 192 million Americans had been fully vaccinated as of Sunday morning, but that is only about 58 percent of the total population.
content: Last year, pre-Thanksgiving concerns centered on social distancing and taking risks with the coronavirus. This year, the focus is inoculation; more than 192 million Americans had been fully vaccinated as of Sunday morning, but that is only about 58 percent of the total population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: The Mystery of ‘Havana Syndrome’
description: The puzzling constellation of symptoms has defied a conclusive answer.
content: A long time ago, soon after I arrived in the Soviet Union as a young wire service reporter and became acutely aware that I was being followed, my eye began to twitch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Richard M. Ohmann, 90, Dies; Brought Radical Politics to College English
description: Inspired by the antiwar movement of the 1960s, he helped transform humanities by making room for subjects like women’s studies and Marxist criticism.
content: Richard M. Ohmann was an unlikely revolutionary. One of the youngest tenured professors in the country, an associate provost at Wesleyan and a former member of the elite Society of Fellows at Harvard, he was the picture of the liberal establishment of the late 1960s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Hari Kumar
title: The W.H.O. grants Covaxin, a Covid vaccine developed in India, emergency authorization.
description: The vaccine is the eighth coronavirus vaccine to receive the global health body’s green light.
content: The World Health Organization on Wednesday granted emergency authorization to Covaxin, the first coronavirus vaccine developed in India and to get the designation, providing a major boost for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who has stressed his intention of making the country’s pandemic prevention effort self-reliant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Maggie Astor
title: Republicans prevail in an expensive race for a seat on Pennsylvania’s Supreme Court.
description: Democrats still control the seven-seat court, which has been thrust into legal battles over coronavirus orders and gerrymandering.
content: Even without presidential contenders fanning out across the state, Pennsylvania presented one of the biggest prizes in this year’s elections, one influencing everything from the governor’s coronavirus powers to redistricting — a seat on the state’s Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Equestrian Jumping Is Set to Be Dropped From Modern Pentathlon
description: Claims of animal abuse at the Tokyo Olympics could lead to the biggest change to modern pentathlon in more than a century.
content: Dwindling interest and a reputation for being outdated couldn’t change modern pentathlon. A brief video clip of a coach punching a horse at the Tokyo Olympics may alter it forever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: John Deere workers reject a revised contract proposal, extending their strike.
description: Workers upset over insufficient wage increases and pension benefits have been on strike since mid-October.
content: [Update: Deere & Company said on Wednesday that it would not resume talks with the union and that the rejected proposal was its best and final offer.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor J. Blue, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Christina Goldbaum
title: ISIS Poses a Growing Threat to New Taliban Government in Afghanistan
description: The Taliban takeover was supposed to bring an end to war, the new government promised. But a growing insurgency is upending security and raising alarms for the international community.
content: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — Aref Mohammad’s war against the Islamic State ended earlier this fall when his unit of Taliban fighters was ambushed by the terrorist group in eastern Afghanistan. A bullet shattered his femur, leaving him disabled and barely able to walk, never mind fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: College Football Playoff Rankings Are an Ode to the Power 5
description: The rankings showed how much organizers favor the most powerful teams in the sport, and they created a hurdle for Cincinnati, which has a marquee win and an undefeated record.
content: If the Cincinnati Bearcats were a cartoon character, they might be Charlie Brown: enthusiastically running up to kick the football only to have Lucy pull it away at the last minute and landing — once again — on his back with a thud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Officials Disclose a ‘Working Theory’ About Jetpack Mystery Over Los Angeles
description: Though the F.B.I. said it was still investigating several pilot reports of seeing someone using a jetpack, it said this week “that pilots might have seen balloons.”
content: The first pilot report of a person flying a jetpack high over Los Angeles was enough to start a federal investigation. The second caused a stir on airport channels, with an air traffic controller remarking, “Only in L.A.” Months after that, a controller warned, “The jetpack guy is back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Buffalo’s mayoral race appears to have swung toward the write-in incumbent, but the count will take time.
description: Byron Brown, a Democrat and four-term mayor, lost to India Walton, a democratic socialist, in a June primary. There are far more write-in votes than votes for her, but determining which belong to Mr. Brown could take weeks.
content: BUFFALO, N.Y. —Mayor Byron W. Brown of Buffalo, an incumbent four-term Democrat, declared victory on Tuesday night in his write-in campaign to defeat his own party’s official nominee, India Walton. But Ms. Walton, a democratic socialist, refused to concede.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Why New Yorkers Rejected Ballot Proposals on Voting and Redistricting
description: Republicans worked hard to defeat the measures, which aimed to broaden ballot access and change the redistricting process. Democrats did little to promote them.
content: In October, the New York’s Republican and Conservative Parties went nuclear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: A New Kind of Native American Dance Troupe
description: Indigenous Enterprise is rooted in tradition but also has hip-hop influences, discernible in footwork, bounce and especially attitude.
content: One day in October, the dancer Kenneth Shirley got a message from Injury Reserve, a hip-hop group he had befriended in Phoenix, where he grew up and still lives. The band was performing in Manhattan and had noticed from Shirley’s Instagram posts that he was on the East Coast, too. Would he like to come to the show as a guest?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: ‘Everything About You Must Say Power’
description: New York City’s new mayor, Eric Adams, pays a lot of attention to what he wears. You should, too.
content: Six years ago, Eric Adams, then Brooklyn borough president, stood onstage at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn and thundered his commencement advice at the soon-to-be graduates.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Bach
description: Listen to all the moods from the grand master of Western classical music: consoling, rousing, peaceful, passionate.
content: In the past we’ve chosen the five minutes or so we would play to make our friends fall in love with classical music, piano, opera, cello, Mozart, 21st-century composers, violin, Baroque music, sopranos, Beethoven, flute, string quartets, tenors, Brahms, choral music, percussion, symphonies, Stravinsky, trumpet and Maria Callas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Takes First Step Toward End of Pandemic Measures
description: The Federal Reserve is dealing with high inflation at a time when millions of workers remain on the job market’s sidelines. Wednesday’s announcement that it will slow bond purchases is a step toward more normal monetary policy.
content: The Federal Reserve on Wednesday took its first step toward withdrawing support for the American economy, saying that it would begin to wind down a stimulus program that’s been in place since early in the pandemic as the economy heals and prices climb at an uncomfortably rapid pace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: The U.S. Air Force hits its vaccine deadline with nearly all troops vaccinated.
description: While the Air Force has the earliest deadline, active duty members in all branches are nearing their goals — until Reserve and National Guard forces are counted.
content: Almost 97 percent of active-duty members of the Air Force — the first branch of the U.S. military to reach its deadline for coronavirus vaccinations — have received at least one dose of vaccine, military officials said Wednesday. That percentage is in line with those for active-duty military members in most branches of service whose deadlines have not yet arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: The New York Sun, a defunct newspaper, plans a comeback after a sale.
description: Seth Lipsky sold the publication to Dovid Efune, the former top editor of The Algemeiner. Mr. Lipsky will remain the top editor, and Mr. Efune will be publisher and chairman.
content: The New York Sun, a daily broadsheet that folded in 2008 after a six-year run, will make an online comeback under new ownership, the paper’s founding editor and its new owner said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Shaffer
title: ‘Simple as Water’ Review: Family Ties That Span the Globe
description: Filmed in five separate countries, this documentary follows, with ambitious scope and devastating intimacy, Syrian families displaced by war.
content: Megan Mylan’s latest documentary feature takes a humble idea — telling intimate and humanizing stories of Syrian families affected by their home country’s civil war — and achieves it on a nakedly ambitious scale. Filmed over five years in five separate countries, “Simple as Water” is anything but simple when it comes to its technical achievements, weaving together familiar immigrant narratives in ways that still manage to surprise and stun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Dan Hinkel
title: Clashing Portrayals of Kyle Rittenhouse in Testimony on Kenosha Shootings
description: Prosecutors described Mr. Rittenhouse as an out-of-town visitor who was armed illegally during tense protests over policing in Kenosha, Wis. His defense team said he was defending himself.
content: KENOSHA, Wis. — On the first day of testimony in the homicide trial of Kyle Rittenhouse, prosecutors and defense lawyers offered sharply divergent portrayals of Mr. Rittenhouse, an 18-year-old from Illinois who faces the prospect of life in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: A Chinese Tennis Star Accuses a Former Top Leader of Sexual Assault
description: Peng Shuai’s accusation against Zhang Gaoli takes the country’s budding #MeToo movement to the top echelons of the Communist Party for the first time.
content: Peng Shuai, the professional tennis star, publicly accused a former vice premier of China of sexual assault, igniting an online firestorm of attention to a #MeToo allegation that for the first time touched the pinnacles of Communist Party power.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Elie Wiesel to ‘The Loneliest Americans’
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: FILLED WITH FIRE AND LIGHT: Portraits and Legends From the Bible, Talmud, and Hasidic World, by Elie Wiesel. (Schocken, $27.) A posthumous collection, edited by Alan Rosen and adapted from a series of Wiesel’s lectures between 1967 and 2014, examines lesser-known biblical figures and encourages a path toward purpose and transcendence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Todd Gregory
title: Mayor Eric Garcetti of Los Angeles tests positive for the virus.
description: Mr. Garcetti’s office said the mayor, who is in Scotland for a conference on climate change, was feeling good and had been fully vaccinated.
content: Mayor Eric Garcetti of Los Angeles tested positive for the coronavirus on Wednesday as he was attending a conference on climate change in Glasgow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
title: Reeling From Surprise Losses, Democrats Sound the Alarm for 2022
description: Party officials say the White House and Congress must do more to address the electorate’s deep malaise or risk watching voters lurch back toward the G.O.P. by default.
content: WASHINGTON — Reeling from a barrage of unexpected losses, an array of Democrats on Wednesday pleaded with President Biden and his party’s lawmakers to address the quality-of-life issues that plagued their candidates in elections on Tuesday from heavily Hispanic San Antonio to the suburbs of Virginia, New Jersey and New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Eshe Nelson
title: Global finance industry says it has $130 trillion to invest in efforts to tackle climate change.
description: The pledge would transform the international financial system, but critics say it falls short on fossil fuels.
content: A coalition of the world’s biggest investors, banks and insurers that collectively control $130 trillion in assets said on Wednesday that they were committing to use that capital to hit net zero emissions targets in their investments by 2050, in a push that would make limiting climate change a central focus of most major financial decisions for decades to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Eric Adams Vows to ‘Get Stuff Done.’ But First, a Night on the Town.
description: The next mayor of New York City, who celebrated at a downtown club, says he will focus on public safety and the crisis at Rikers Island.
content: After more than a decade of plotting his path to becoming mayor of New York City, Eric Adams won a decisive victory on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: As deadlines loom, the U.S. military grants few vaccine exemptions.
description: Two months after the Pentagon began requiring all troops to get the coronavirus vaccine or face dismissal, the vast majority have now had shots, in part because none received a religious exemption, military officials said.
content: Two months after the Pentagon began requiring all troops to get the coronavirus vaccine or face dismissal, the vast majority have now had shots, in part because none received a religious exemption, military officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and James Dobbins
title: A Republican narrowly flipped a State House seat in San Antonio.
description: John Lujan, a 59-year-old retired firefighter, won the seat, a blow for Democrats in the Texas city.
content: SAN ANTONIO — Growing up in a working-class neighborhood in San Antonio, Adolfo Chagoy had long supported local and national Democrats who touted job growth and infrastructure projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: We Need to Talk About the Dark Side of Daylight Saving Time
description: Why are we still changing our clocks twice a year?
content: On Nov. 7, most of us will fall back an hour and restart the decades-old discussion of why we shift time twice a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Would You Ever Want to Run a Marathon?
description: Is that the kind of challenge that appeals to you? If not, what other feat of time and dedication might you take on someday?
content: A marathon is 26.2 miles. Many people who enter these races feel that simply crossing the finish line is an accomplishment, though others try to get there as fast as they can without risking injury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Paul Newman Will Tell His Own Story, 14 Years After His Death
description: Knopf plans to publish a book next year based on hours of recordings the movie star left behind, as well as interviews with family, friends and associates.
content: Decades ago, the actor and philanthropist Paul Newman, frustrated by all the unauthorized biographies and coverage of his life, recorded his own oral history, leaving behind transcripts that for years were forgotten in the basement laundry room of his house in Connecticut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Republicans Schooled the Left in Virginia
description: Democrats probably need a new way to talk about race and education.
content: After Terry McAuliffe stumbled to defeat in a state that Joe Biden won by 10 points exactly one year ago tonight, a mild suggestion seems in order: Democrats probably need a new way to talk about progressive ideology and education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Jeremy W. Peters
title: Republicans Pounce on Schools as a Wedge Issue to Unite the Party
description: Rallying around what it calls “parental rights,” the party is pushing to build on its victories this week by stoking white resentment and tapping into broader anger at the education system.
content: After an unexpectedly strong showing on Tuesday night, Republicans are heading into the 2022 midterm elections with what they believe will be a highly effective political strategy capitalizing on the frustrations of suburban parents still reeling from the devastating fallout of pandemic-era schooling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Mike Duggan wins a third term as Detroit’s mayor.
description: Mr. Duggan, a Democrat, has presided over a resurgence of Detroit’s downtown and a restoration of basic city services, even as many neighborhoods continue to struggle.
content: Mayor Mike Duggan of Detroit was elected to a third term on Tuesday, The Associated Press projected, as voters signaled confidence in the direction of a city that has suffered from decades of disinvestment and population loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian
title: Meet the new meme stocks? Shares of Avis and Bed Bath & Beyond soar.
description: The moves appeared linked to several factors, including positive corporate announcements, a surge in interest from retail investors and the squeezing of short sellers.
content: Shares of the rental car company Avis Budget Group more than doubled on Tuesday, in a sudden and unexpected surge that recalled earlier trading manias in GameStop, AMC Entertainment and other so-called meme stocks. Bed Bath & Beyond, the retailer that attracted some interest during previous meme-stock episodes, also rose sharply in late trading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: ‘Tammany Hall’ Votes the Party Line
description: An immersive show at the SoHo Playhouse takes theatergoers back to a speakeasy in 1929, when New York was also in a mayoral race.
content: On Tuesday, New York’s citizens weighed in on a mayoral race between a vegan former police captain and a beret-wearing cat enthusiast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: E-Scooters, E-Bikes
description: Have you ridden one of these? Are they a good idea, or are they too dangerous for crowded cities?
content: A boom in electric-powered mobile devices is bringing what is likely to be a lasting change to New York’s vast and crowded street grid — and to cities around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Eshe Nelson
title: Janet Yellen, the Treasury secretary, says the U.S. will help raise $500 million for green bonds.
description: Ms. Yellen said wealthy countries had pledged billions of dollars to tackle climate change, but the real cost is in the trillions.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said on Wednesday that the United States would support a financing mechanism that aims to direct $500 million a year to move developing countries away from coal-based energy and toward wind, solar and other low- and zero-carbon energy sources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Sunao Tsuboi, 96, Dies; Hiroshima Victim Who Lived to Tell His Story
description: After suffering through the agony of the attack and its aftermath, he devoted himself to spreading the message that nuclear weapons should be abolished.
content: Sunao Tsuboi, who as a 20-year-old engineering student found himself less than a mile from the center of the atomic blast at Hiroshima and somehow survived, and who went on to devote himself to the cause of nuclear disarmament, including in a much-publicized meeting with President Barack Obama in 2016, died on Oct. 24 at a hospital in Hiroshima. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Patrick McGeehan
title: With Cuomo Gone, Hochul Revises Plan for Penn Station
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul is putting her own stamp on former Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s proposal, focusing on rebuilding the huge station but putting off its expansion.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul put her imprint on an ambitious plan to restore Pennsylvania Station on Wednesday, saying she would place a priority on improvements at the busy rail hub while scaling back a development deal that her predecessor launched to help fund the project.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Julianne Boyd to Retire After 27 Years at Barrington Stage
description: Under her leadership, the nonprofit produced “The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee” and other shows that made it to Broadway.
content: Julianne Boyd, who has served as artistic director of Barrington Stage Company since cofounding the Western Massachusetts nonprofit in 1995, will retire next fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Black voters in Virginia refuse to be blamed for a major Democratic defeat.
description: Black state leaders and voters said the results were a sign that the party could not rely on minority voters to cover its cratering totals in white areas of the state.
content: NEWPORT NEWS, Va. — Democrats across Virginia expressed profound disappointment on Wednesday after Republicans romped to an unlikely victory in the governor’s race, an ominous sign for the Democratic Party ahead of next year’s midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Tom Matte, Emergency Quarterback for Baltimore Colts, Dies at 82
description: A gritty running back, he was enlisted to replace Johnny Unitas and his backup as quarterback in critical games in 1965. He wore a wristband to remember the plays.
content: Tom Matte, a stubby halfback for the Baltimore Colts who stepped in as their quarterback late in the 1965 season when Johnny Unitas and his backup, Gary Cuozzo, were injured and nearly took the team to the N.F.L. championship game, died on Tuesday at his home in Towson, Md. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘The Harder They Fall’ Review: A New Look for the Old West
description: Jeymes Samuel’s film is a bloody horse opera with a charismatic cast.
content: A note at the beginning of “The Harder They Fall” asserts that while the story is fictional, “These. People. Existed.” This isn’t about historical accuracy, or even realism; it’s about genre. The movie, directed by Jeymes Samuel (from a screenplay he wrote with Boaz Yakin), is a high-style pop Western, with geysers of blood, winks of nasty, knowing humor and an eclectic, joyfully anachronistic soundtrack featuring cuts from Jay-Z, Fela Kuti and Nina Simone alongside Samuel’s original score.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: When the Soccer Is Just a Story Line
description: In a steady stream of documentary series, more and more clubs are turning themselves into content. But where does spectacle end and sport begin?
content: LONDON — The cameras were rolling even before the actors Ryan Reynolds and Rob McElhenney could be sure there would be anything to film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Ballot initiatives to increase housing won big on Tuesday, a possible harbinger for 2022.
description: The trend could be a harbinger of more ballot choices in 2022, as more cities and states take aim at rising rents.
content: A slew of initiatives aimed at the addressing the nation’s housing crisis passed on Tuesday, a test run for ballot choices in 2022 as more cities and states take aim at rising rents, a continued explosion in short-term rentals and the depressed housing stock nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

title: After a Gloomy Summit Start, Hints of Progress
description: Leaders reached agreements to reduce methane gas emissions and protect the world’s forests. Now, the really hard part begins.
content: The world leaders gathered at the climate summit in Glasgow secured new agreements on Tuesday to end deforestation and reduce emissions of methane, a potent greenhouse gas. Now, the conference shifts to a more grueling phase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Virginia Goes Red
description: Republicans had a good election night.
content: Democrats had a rough election night. They lost the governor’s race in Virginia, a state Joe Biden won by 10 percentage points only a year ago. In New Jersey, which Biden won by 16 points, the governor’s election is too close to call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Developments at the COP26 climate summit.
content: National leaders at the COP26 climate summit agreed on two significant advances on climate change: promises to curb methane emissions and a deal to end deforestation by 2030.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Duterte vows to punish Philippine officials for slow vaccine delivery.
description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines has warned local officials that they will be punished if they fail to meet vaccination targets as the country slowly reopens.
content: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines has warned local officials that they will be punished if they fail to meet vaccination targets as the country slowly reopens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Damon Galgut Wins Booker Prize for ‘The Promise’
description: The novelist, shortlisted for two of his previous books, received one of the world’s most prestigious literary awards for his cutting depiction of a white family in post-apartheid South Africa.
content: When the South African writer Damon Galgut learned that his novel, “The Promise,” was shortlisted for the Booker Prize, he was filled with anxiety. Galgut had been shortlisted twice before, in 2003 and 2010, and both times, the stress of the nominations “probably shaved a few years off my life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Trump, who had little engagement with Youngkin’s campaign, claims credit for his victory.
description: “Without MAGA, he would have lost by 15 points or more,” the former president said in a radio interview.
content: CHANTILLY, Va. — Former President Donald J. Trump never appeared in public with Glenn Youngkin, Virginia’s new Republican governor-elect. Other than delivering a six-minute speech during a conference call with supporters on Monday and issuing a few written statements, Mr. Trump was not that involved in Mr. Youngkin’s campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Big Warning Signs for the Biden Economic Agenda
description: Republican victories portend more trouble for Democrats’ legislative efforts.
content: Republicans scored big in yesterday’s elections. Most notably, the former private equity mogul Glenn Youngkin won the race for Virginia’s governorship. It is a major warning sign for President Biden and Democrats that their legislative plans are under threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: With Mammoth Blasts, Jorge Soler Wins World Series M.V.P.
description: He was hitting .192 when Atlanta traded for him and missed time with the coronavirus. But Soler’s homers put his team ahead in three games in the series.
content: HOUSTON — Growing up in Cuba, Atlanta Braves outfielder Jorge Soler was already so tall by around 9 or 10, his father said, that people didn’t believe his age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘A Civil Rights Pioneer Seeks to Have Her Record Cleared’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about Claudette Colvin, a 15-year-old who stood up for equal rights in 1955. Then, they will reflect on a time when they took a stand on an important issue.
content: Featured Article: “A Civil Rights Pioneer Seeks to Have Her Record Cleared” by Eduardo Medina
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer, Lisa Friedman and Eshe Nelson
title: Climate Summit Turns Its Focus to a Contentious Question: Who Pays?
description: Even as financial institutions vowed to mobilize trillions in capital toward clean energy, developing countries say they are still struggling to pay the costs of adapting to the dangers of global warming.
content: GLASGOW — Some of the world’s biggest financial institutions on Wednesday vowed to mobilize trillions of dollars to help shift the global economy toward cleaner energy as negotiators at the United Nations climate summit struggled with the question of how to pay for the enormous costs of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A pandemic election.
content: American elections are typically fought over a semi-fixed set of central issues — pocketbook concerns, schools, whether voters feel like things are going well for them. But in yesterday’s contests, the pandemic played an outsized role in two strong Republican showings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Ethiopia’s Leader Vows to ‘Bury This Enemy,’ Even as Rebels Advance
description: A United Nations report, released as Tigrayan rebels near the capital, documents atrocities on all sides in a year-old civil war.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — As rebel fighters drew closer to the capital on Wednesday, Ethiopia’s embattled leader appealed to his soldiers to defend the city “with our blood,” in a stark and inflammatory speech that heightened the mounting air of crisis in Africa’s second-most populous country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Giulia Heyward
title: Only 1 Black Juror Is Chosen for Trial Over Ahmaud Arbery’s Killing
description: After a grueling selection process, opening statements in the case against three white men accused of chasing down and killing Mr. Arbery are expected to begin on Friday.
content: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — After a grueling process that lasted two and a half weeks, a jury was selected on Wednesday in the trial of the three white men accused of killing Ahmaud Arbery, the 25-year-old Black man who was chased through a suburban Georgia neighborhood before being fatally shot by one of his pursuers in February 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorie Greenspan
title: It’s Apple Season. This Galette Cuts the Chill With a Kick.
description: Dorie Greenspan makes a savory tart with apple, sweet potato, cheese and a touch of chile pepper.
content: A few weeks ago, when I called Krissy Scommegna, the 32-year-old owner of the Boonville Barn Collective in Boonville, Calif., she was taking a break after clocking three hours in the greenhouse pulling off the stems and shaking out the seeds from 750 pounds of chiles. I wasn’t quick enough to do the math, but because she, a few friends who came to lend a hand and the three people who work with her had harvested 15,000 pounds of peppers in their first pass across the fields, I figured they had a lot to do before the second harvest, and the third. All those peppers have to be picked, set in the greenhouses for a time, stemmed and seeded, dehydrated, ground, scooped and sealed into jars. “We grow esoteric chiles,” Krissy said with a full and easy laugh, “but we’re a down-to-earth farm.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: A Sinking Student Housing Empire
description: An ambitious property management company that pitches upscale off-campus apartments across the country has left tenants and investors stewing.
content: Between the busted elevators, the malfunctioning fire alarms and the utilities being shut off for weeks at a time, the students at a half-dozen off-campus housing complexes across the country say they’re not getting what they paid for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: A Dose of Optimism About Mothers at Work
description: The economist Claudia Goldin has hope for the future.
content: This article has been updated to reflect news events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Atlanta Had to Celebrate Its Title Without Its Architect
description: Home after testing positive for Covid-19, Alex Anthopoulos missed the party that wouldn’t have been possible without his brilliant deadline maneuvers.
content: HOUSTON — The Covid-19 test came back positive Saturday morning. The man who crushed the trade deadline by bringing in four outfielders who would carry his team through the World Series was now crushed himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: European Steel Plan Shows Biden’s Bid to Merge Climate and Trade Policy
description: A potential agreement on steel trade provides the clearest look yet at how the Biden administration plans to implement a trade policy that is both protectionist and progressive
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden has promised to use trade policy as a tool to mitigate climate change. This weekend, the administration provided its first look at how it plans to mesh those policy goals, saying the United States and the European Union would try to curb carbon emissions as part of a trade deal covering steel and aluminum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooke Jarvis
title: Did Covid Change How We Dream?
description: All around the world, the pandemic provoked strange nocturnal visions. Can they help shed light on the age-old question of why we dream at all?
content: Deirdre Barrett’s body was in bed, but her mind was in a library. The library was inside a very old house, with glowing oil lamps and shelves of beautiful leatherbound books. At first it felt snug and secure and timeless, exactly the sort of place an academic like Barrett, who teaches in the psychiatry department at Harvard Medical School and edits the scientific journal Dreaming, might find inviting. But as the dream went on, she remembered later, “I became less able to focus on the library and more overwhelmed by the unseen horror outside.” Beyond the windows of the softly lit library, “a terrible plague was ravaging the world.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Block Your Phone from Interrupting You
description: If the apps, alerts and action on your smartphone are taking up too much of your attention, turn on Focus mode to mute the distractions.
content: Sometimes, you just need to get stuff done — that budget spreadsheet, your novel or even a nap — but your smartphone insists on distracting you with notifications, texts or the pull of social media. Sure, the Do Not Disturb setting can temporarily stifle interruptions when you need quiet time or a mental break, but recent versions of Android and Apple’s new iOS 15 include a more flexible Focus mode with other tools for concentration. Here’s a quick guide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Emily Cochrane
title: Democrats, Stung by Losses, Press Forward on Biden Agenda
description: Disappointed by a defeat in Virginia and a closer-than-expected race in New Jersey, Democrats were working toward quick action on key bills to show they could govern.
content: WASHINGTON — Smarting from an off-year electoral rebuke, congressional Democrats pushed forward on Wednesday toward House votes as soon as Thursday on nearly $3 trillion worth of social policy, infrastructure and climate change programs — but with a deep new worry: Would a legislative victory help or hurt their bruised political standing?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Analyze a Photo, Write a Story, Reflect on Community
description: Each week, we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday, we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to learn about Indigenous environmental activism, recommend new music, tell us a story, closely analyze a photograph and watch a short film about a beachfront haven for Black families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The New Magazine Alexander Hamilton Might Have Written For
description: National Development calls for a strong government guiding a more self-sufficient economy.
content: National Development is the online magazine that Alexander Hamilton might have written for if web zines had existed in 1787. The magazine, which debuted on Sept. 17, is devoted to what Hamilton, the first secretary of the Treasury, fought for: a strong national government that guides and helps the development of a productive, more self-sufficient economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: India Walton says that she likely cannot beat the write-in incumbent, Byron Brown, in the race for Buffalo’s mayor.
description: “It seems unlikely that we will end up with enough votes to inaugurate a Walton administration in January,” the democratic socialist wrote on Twitter.
content: BUFFALO, N.Y. — In a sharp reversal of political fortune, Mayor Byron W. Brown of Buffalo has seemingly triumphed in a write-in campaign for a new term, besting India Walton, a democratic socialist who had stunned Mr. Brown in a primary in June and had drawn national attention as a champion of progressive values.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: New Funding Offshoot Expands Grants to Arts Groups in the Southeast
description: As part of the Southern Cultural Treasures program, the Ford Foundation and an Atlanta nonprofit will funnel aid to arts groups led by people of color in that region.
content: Last year, when the Ford Foundation announced an initiative to give more than $100 million to arts groups run by people of color, none of the 20 initial recipients were in the Southeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justices’ Questions Suggest New York Gun Control Law Is Unlikely to Survive
description: The law, which imposes strict limits on carrying guns in public, faced a skeptical reception from the Supreme Court on Wednesday.
content: WASHINGTON — A New York law that imposes strict limits on carrying guns outside the home seemed unlikely to survive its encounter with the Supreme Court, based on questioning from the justices on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Hastings Law to Change Name Linked to Native Massacres
description: A Times article helped galvanize a push to rename the school, whose founder masterminded the slaughter of Yuki men, women and children.
content: As a law student in 1950s San Francisco, Willie Brown paid little heed to the name of the school he was attending: the Hastings College of the Law, named after the state’s first chief justice, whose dark past was not widely known.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: South Africa secured $8.5 billion to transition away from coal. It’ll be a test case.
description: Developing nations have long said they need aid from wealthy countries to shift to renewable energy. South Africa may show how that would work in practice.
content: For years at global climate talks, developing countries have said that they need more financial help from wealthy nations to speed up their shift away from fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen McNamara
title: Michelle Wu Proved That Boston Isn’t the Same Old Boston Anymore
description: Her election represents a seismic shift to the political landscape of the city.
content: BOSTON — Time to retire the tired old tropes about Brahmin swells, Irish ward heelers and the petty parochialism that for too long has defined this city on the national stage. A Taiwanese American woman from Chicago is about to become the mayor of Boston, a town that, until Tuesday, had elected only white men to that office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Max Fried Lost Game 2. Then He Pitched Atlanta to a Title.
description: Atlanta’s ace erased the memory of a bad outing by keeping Houston off balance and throwing six scoreless innings.
content: HOUSTON — Max Fried had last left Minute Maid Park’s mound in frustration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Here are five takeaways from the election results.
description: The victory by Glenn Youngkin in the Virginia governor’s race delivered a jolt of encouragement for Republicans and a stark warning sign for the Democrats.
content: Glenn Youngkin, a Republican business executive, marched to victory in Tuesday’s election, delivering his party the governorship of Virginia and highlighting a strong night for Republicans less than a year after voters pushed them fully out of power in the nation’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Spain is facing the loss of a major source of natural gas.
description: Algeria, locked in a dispute with Morocco, has shut down a significant gas pipeline.
content: Algeria has stopped supplying gas through one of its main pipelines that crosses Morocco, a move that could threaten Spain with reduced supplies or higher prices for natural gas as winter approaches and energy costs are soaring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: Video Footage Showed at Least 1 Child Near Site Minutes Before Drone Strike in Kabul
description: An investigation of the Aug. 29 airstrike, which mistakenly killed 10 civilians, including seven children, did not recommend any disciplinary action.
content: WASHINGTON — Surveillance videos showed the presence of at least one child in the area some two minutes before the military launched a drone strike on a site in Kabul, Afghanistan, in August, the Defense Department said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Smartmatic Sues Newsmax and One America News Network, Claiming Defamation
description: Smartmatic, an election technology company that faced baseless accusations of rigging the 2020 election, has filed a similar lawsuit against Fox News.
content: The legal battle against disinformation from right-wing media outlets is expanding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: anomaly
description: This word has appeared in 135 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carla Correa
title: Attention, New Englanders: Fluffernutter Is Now a Word
description: What has prompted Merriam-Webster to add the longstanding term for a mostly regional sandwich to the dictionary?
content: New England is where Marshmallow Fluff was created more than 100 years ago, and is still made and largely consumed — often by children in a peanut butter and Marshmallow Fluff sandwich.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In photos: Candidates celebrate victories on election night.
description: Candidates in Virginia, Ohio, New York City and Boston celebrate their victories in Tuesday’s elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Cardio Before Weight Lifting May Help Boost Muscle
description: Twenty minutes of cycling may prime muscles in the arms to grow more while lifting.
content: Riding or running before you lift weights could amplify the effects of the lifting, according to a helpful new study of the molecular impacts of combining endurance and resistance exercise in a single workout. The study, which involved eight physically active men, found that 20 minutes of intense cycling right before an upper-body weight routine alters the inner workings of muscles, priming them to change and grow more than with lifting alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Children 5 to 11 in N.Y.C. can start getting Covid shots Thursday, the mayor said.
description: The city was awaiting the arrival of federal clinical guidelines for providers before administering shots, the mayor said, though the state said the city did not have to wait.
content: Coronavirus vaccinations for children 5 to 11 years old are expected to begin Thursday in New York City, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Wednesday. City officials said there were more than 230,000 pediatric doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine already on hand in the city or on their way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James A. Morone
title: The Decade That Changed America Forever
description: Kevin Boyle’s “The Shattering” tells the story of the profound disruptures that rocked the country in the 1960s.
content: THE SHATTERING America in the 1960sBy Kevin Boyle
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Poland and 17 other countries to announce a major deal to end coal.
description: The countries, banks and other organizations that make up a new coalition will commit to ending all investment in new coal power generation domestically and internationally.
content: A coalition of 18 countries, plus dozens of banks and other institutions, will pledge to phase out coal-fired power plants domestically and to end funding for international coal projects, according to the British government, which struck the deal at a global climate summit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Election Day Silver Linings!
description: Really, it could have been worse.
content: Walking to the polls on Election Day, I suddenly had a vision of all my neighbors trying to break out of the doldrums by voting for Curtis Sliwa for mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully, Nick Corasaniti and Katie Glueck
title: Murphy Narrowly Wins Re-election as New Jersey’s Governor
description: The victory over Jack Ciattarelli, which ended Democrats’ 44-year re-election losing streak in the state, was far tighter than polls had predicted.
content: Philip D. Murphy, a New Jersey Democrat whose aggressive approach to controlling the pandemic became a focal point of the bid to unseat him, narrowly held onto the governor’s office in an unexpectedly close election that highlighted stark divisions over mask and vaccine mandates, even in a liberal-leaning state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Tanier
title: In N.F.L. Awards Race, M.V.P. Won’t Be the Only Close Call
description: Bills quarterback Josh Allen and Rams receiver Cooper Kupp could prevent the Cowboys from sweeping the N.F.L. season awards.
content: Before Sunday’s right foot injury derailed his season, Tennessee Titans running back Derrick Henry deserved consideration, and probably rejection, for the 2021 N.F.L. Most Valuable Player Award.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: From BTS to ‘Squid Game’: How South Korea Became a Cultural Juggernaut
description: The country was once largely known for cars and smartphones, but a global audience has become mesmerized by its entertainment, and creators say success didn’t happen overnight.
content: PAJU, South Korea — In a new Korean drama being filmed inside a cavernous studio building outside of Seoul, a detective chases down a man cursed to live for 600 years. Pistol shots crack. A hush follows. Then, a woman pierces the silence, screaming: “I told you not to shoot him in ​the heart!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: San Francisco Police Officer Charged With Shooting Man Who Died 3 Years Later
description: Officer Kenneth Cha, charged with voluntary manslaughter, “lacked a lawful basis to even arrest” the man and “elevated a nonviolent encounter,” the district attorney said.
content: A San Francisco police officer was charged with voluntary manslaughter for shooting an unarmed man who died three years after being wounded at his home in 2017, the San Francisco district attorney’s office announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: This Fish Loses 20 Teeth Each Day, Then Grows Them All Back
description: One fish, two fish. Green fish, blue fish. Outer teeth, inner teeth. These fish grow a lot of teeth.
content: If there is one place you don’t want to stick your finger, it’s the mouth of a Pacific lingcod. These fearsome fish, which can grow up to five feet in length and weigh 80 pounds, have around 500 needlelike teeth sticking out of jaws that are strong enough to crush crustaceans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Virginia’s Fight Over ‘Beloved’
description: Glenn Youngkin leveraged “parents’ rights” to win the governor’s race.
content: Today, we look at the fight over “parents’ rights” in Virginia and the future of masks in schools — and readers offer their homework tips.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 3 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
description: Shannon Cartier Lucy’s luminous scenes of unease; Manoucher Yektai’s lyrical impasto works; and Dread Scott’s “Slave Rebellion Reenactment.”
content: When the Nashville-born artist Shannon Cartier Lucy, who had earlier success with a conceptual practice, re-emerged last year after a decade-long absence from the art world, it was with a crisp, realistic style. This show is her second at Lubov, a small gallery in a worn walk-up in Chinatown whose office space remnants make it seem as though the previous tenants absconded in the middle of the night. The setting adds to the through-the-looking-glass quality of Lucy’s paintings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Atlanta Overcomes Decades of Frustration to Win World Series
description: A dominant all-around effort secured a Game 6 win, allowing an 88-win team to beat the Houston Astros and triumph at a stage that more celebrated Braves teams of the past usually struggled.
content: HOUSTON — So, this is the Braves team that found a way to match the great Atlanta teams of the 1990s. This team, with no trio of Hall of Fame aces, no legendary manager and no backlog of World Series experience to build on, somehow found a way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Republicans score key wins in district attorney races on Long Island.
description: Raymond Tierney won the race in Suffolk County, N.Y., with his Democratic opponent conceding late Tuesday night.
content: Republicans won two highly competitive district attorney races on Long Island that were seen as key tests of Democratic strength in the suburbs and support for left-leaning criminal justice measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Deere says it won’t resume talks after striking workers reject an agreement.
description: It was the second contract proposal to be voted down by union members at the farm machinery company.
content: One day after workers at the agriculture equipment maker Deere & Company voted down a second contract proposal, the company said Wednesday that the proposal was its best and final offer and that it had no plans to resume bargaining.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Killed in a 1961 Crash, ‘Unknown Boy’ Is Finally Identified
description: The mystery of a teenage hitchhiker, now identified as Daniel Paul Armantrout, was solved 60 years later because of advances in DNA technology and genealogy.
content: They called him “Unknown Boy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: House Democrats Revive Paid Leave Program, Ignoring Manchin’s Concerns
description: The House plans to add a provision to provide four weeks of federally paid family and medical leave to their social policy bill, but it is all but certain to be jettisoned by the Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California announced on Wednesday that she would include four weeks of federal paid family and medical leave in the $1.85 trillion domestic policy bill that the House plans to consider as early as Thursday, seeking to pressure Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia to drop his opposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Greece tightens restrictions on the unvaccinated as virus cases spike.
description: The restrictions start Saturday and target unvaccinated people, said the country’s health minister, Thanos Plevris.
content: As Greece broke another record in daily coronavirus infections this week, registering 6,700 new cases within the past 24 hours, the country’s health minister announced a series of new restrictions aimed at flattening the spike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: For the Astros, a Stinging Loss and an Uncertain Future
description: Houston’s experience couldn’t save it in the World Series. With Carlos Correa hinting he might leave, there is no telling what the team might look like next season.
content: HOUSTON — Dusty Baker talked eloquently over the weekend about how this particular group of Houston Astros was gritty and battle-tested. After a win in Atlanta pulled the team to within three games to two in this World Series, he and star shortstop Carlos Correa both spoke of this team’s knack for dramatic comebacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: The ‘Third Rail of American Politics’ Is Still Electrifying
description: Polling on immigration shows a strong shift to the left, but survey responses in that vein mask a far more complicated reality.
content: Although public polling on immigration shows a strong shift to the left, survey responses in that vein mask a far more complicated reality. Over and over again, immigration has proved to be politically problematic for Democrats. As far back as 2007, when he was chairman of the House Democratic Caucus, Rahm Emanuel warned that immigration had become the new “third rail of American politics.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Margaret York, an L.A.P.D. Model for ‘Cagney & Lacey,’ Dies at 80
description: She became the police force’s highest ranking woman after she and a detective partner inspired a TV series fighting crime in the streets and sexism in the ranks.
content: Margaret York, a homicide detective who helped inspire the 1980s Emmy-winning police drama “Cagney & Lacey,” and who rose to become the highest-ranking woman in the Los Angeles Police Department, died on Oct. 17 at a hospital in Los Angeles. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Alice Childress Finally Gets to Make ‘Trouble’ on Broadway
description: Her prescient 1955 play about racism in the theater world is reaching the big stage. And it’s anything but a period piece.
content: Wiletta Mayer walks into the theater already knowing how things will go. Smartly dressed, attractive and middle-aged (don’t ask for a number, because “a woman that’ll tell her age will tell anything”), she is a veteran actress who’s played maids and mammies and knows how to cater to white directors and producers. You can call it “Uncle Tomming.” Or you can call it plain common sense. Either way, it’s a living.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Youngkin’s Dance With Trump Was Pivotal. But Is It Repeatable?
description: Glenn Youngkin’s victory in Virginia may inspire Republican imitators vying to win over Trump supporters without embracing the former president outright.
content: Since he burst onto the national political scene in 2015, Donald J. Trump has strong-armed one Republican after another into submission. But in Virginia, Glenn Youngkin did something new: He managed to keep the former president at a politically safe remove without alienating him or his allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Republicans broke through in Virginia, but not for the usual reasons.
description: Glenn Youngkin won by making broad gains over Democrats in every part of the state and, apparently, across every demographic group.
content: Over the last two decades, American politics has steadily polarized along urban and rural lines, with Democrats running up the score in well-educated metropolitan areas and Republicans making gains in the countryside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Tim Arango
title: Offered a Chance to Reinvent Policing, Minneapolis Opts for What It Knows
description: Around the country, local elections suggested that voters were rejecting the most sweeping calls to reinvent law enforcement.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — After a Minneapolis police officer murdered George Floyd last year, protesters marched across the country demanding sweeping change to law enforcement. But given the opportunity Tuesday to dismantle their city’s troubled Police Department and replace it with something new, Minneapolis voters said no.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Alvin Bragg Wins, Becoming First Black D.A. in Manhattan
description: A former federal prosecutor, Mr. Bragg will take over an office that has brought charges against the family business of former president Donald J. Trump.
content: Alvin Bragg was elected Manhattan district attorney on Tuesday and will become the first Black person to lead the influential office, which handles tens of thousands of cases a year and is conducting a high-profile investigation into former President Donald J. Trump and his family business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: When Women Filmmakers Get to Tell Their Origin Stories
description: Movies about men who make movies are common, but female auteurs don’t often get such chances. That’s just one reason two new releases are so surprising.
content: The newly released “The Souvenir Part II” and “Bergman Island” are both films by modern masters that not only delve into the filmmaking process but also draw from the personal lives of the filmmakers themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Nicole Perlroth, Ana Swanson and Ronen Bergman
title: U.S. Blacklists Israeli Firm NSO Group Over Spyware
description: The ban is the strongest step an American president has taken to curb abuses in the global market for spyware.
content: In a remarkable breach with Israel over one of its most successful technology companies, the Biden administration on Wednesday blacklisted the NSO Group, saying the company knowingly supplied spyware that has been used by foreign governments to “maliciously target” the phones of dissidents, human rights activists, journalists and others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: Memo to Republicans: This Is How You Lose Gracefully
description: Democracy requires that the loser accept the legitimacy of the process.
content: Glenn Youngkin’s victory over Terry McAuliffe in the Virginia governor’s race surprised many people in a state that has been trending blue for years. Republican candidates also won the other top races in the state, for lieutenant governor and attorney general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: Should Classic Rock Songs Be Toppled Like Confederate Statues?
description: It’s time to reconsider our pop culture icons.
content: A long, long time ago — I can still remember how that music used to make me smile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Young Children Are Lining Up for Next Wave of Covid Vaccines
description: Many parents have been anxiously waiting for the moment their 5- to 11-year-olds could be inoculated. That day has arrived.
content: In Houston, Texas Children’s Hospital on Wednesday morning tackled the first of some 35,000 pediatric Covid-19 vaccine appointments, a rush that officials said had been booked in just five days. Nationally, Walgreens and CVS pharmacies opened appointment lines for millions of miniature doses. And amid a deluge of demand from parents desperate to get their children at least partially inoculated by Thanksgiving, Dr. Eric Ball realized he would have to skip some of his friend’s daughter’s bat mitzvah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Jacob Frey, who oversaw Minneapolis when George Floyd was murdered, wins a second term as mayor.
description: The mayoral race was shaped by Mr. Floyd’s death at the hands of a police officer and the debate about whether to replace the city’s Police Department.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Mayor Jacob Frey, a Democrat who led Minneapolis when a police officer murdered George Floyd and the city was overwhelmed by rioting last year, was elected to a second term, The Associated Press projected on Wednesday. Mr. Frey also had opposed efforts to abolish or replace the local police force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Michelle Wu is the first woman and first person of color to be elected mayor of Boston.
description: “We are ready to be a Boston for everyone,” said Ms. Wu, whose campaign was buoyed by support from the city’s young, left-leaning voters and by Black, Asian and Latino residents.
content: BOSTON — Michelle Wu, who entered public service out of frustration with the obstacles that her immigrant family faced, will be the next mayor of Boston, pledging to make the city a proving ground for progressive policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Eric Adams Is Elected Mayor of New York City
description: Mr. Adams, a Democrat and former police captain, will be the second Black mayor in the city’s history.
content: Eric Leroy Adams, a former New York City police captain whose attention-grabbing persona and keen focus on racial justice fueled a decades-long career in public life, was elected on Tuesday as the 110th mayor of New York and the second Black mayor in the city’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman, Michael Gold, Katie Glueck and Troy Closson
title: Voting is over and a winner is expected tonight in the New York City mayor’s race.
description: It is unclear when a winner will be declared, but in the 2013 election, the last open-seat mayoral race in the city, the contest was called less than an hour after polls closed.
content: Polls closed in New York City at 9 p.m., as Eric Adams and Curtis Sliwa waited to learn which of them voters had chosen to lead the nation’s largest city out of the throes of the pandemic and into a new political era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Your Garden Isn’t Winding Down: It’s Still Lichen Season
description: After the distraction of fall leaves has passed, don’t assume that your garden is dormant. It’s time to appreciate the beauty of lichen.
content: What are lichens? They are neither plant nor animal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Colorado hospitals are nearly full as the state battles a growing caseload.
description: Medical facilities can turn new patients away after available capacity dropped to 10 percent in many places. The number of daily new cases in the state has soared to levels not seen since November 2020.
content: Colorado is experiencing its worst coronavirus wave in a year and its overwhelmed hospitals are now allowed to turn away new patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iman Stevenson
title: Aunjanue Ellis Leans Into a Supporting Role and Turns It Into a Talker
description: The actress is used to secondary parts, but with “King Richard” she is being singled out for her turn as the mother of Venus and Serena Williams.
content: The actress Aunjanue Ellis is nearly 30 years into an onscreen career, but until about a decade ago, she thought it was all a fluke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Satellites Could Help Track if Nations Keep Their Carbon Pledges
description: Scientists used satellite measurements of carbon dioxide to detect small atmospheric reductions over areas under coronavirus lockdowns. The approach could help track emissions more quickly in the future.
content: Under the 2015 Paris Agreement to limit global warming, nations must measure and report progress toward their pledged reductions in emissions. They regularly submit greenhouse gas inventories, detailing emission sources as well as removals, or sinks, of the gases within their borders. These are then reviewed by technical experts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Lawyers for ‘Rust’ Armorer Say Gun Was Briefly Unattended Before Shooting
description: The weapon handed to Alec Baldwin was left on a tray for several minutes, said the lawyers. Earlier, they had said it had been unattended for hours.
content: The lawyers for the armorer on the film “Rust” — who has been under scrutiny since Alec Baldwin fatally shot the movie’s cinematographer with a gun that was not supposed to contain live ammunition — said in interviews on Wednesday that the gun had been left unattended for hours, but later corrected themselves to say it had only been several minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina and Maggie Astor
title: Shontel Brown, a Democrat, wins an Ohio House seat in a special election.
description: The district, Ohio’s 11th Congressional District, encompasses most of Cleveland and much of Akron.
content: Shontel Brown, a Democrat, won a House seat in a special election in Cleveland on Tuesday, defeating her Republican opponent, Laverne Gore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Governments must create millions of new green jobs, Ban Ki-moon says.
description: His comments come amid rising concern that transitioning to a greener economy could provoke a backlash if the cost falls to low- and middle-income people.
content: Global leaders must create jobs in the renewable energy sector so that the costs of transitioning from fossil fuels do not exacerbate economic inequalities, Ban Ki-moon, the former United Nations secretary general, said on Wednesday on the sidelines of the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: A protest outside the main summit venue calls out ‘greenwashing’ by big companies.
description: As the focus of the Glasgow summit turns to funding, protesters call for greater accountability for companies’ climate promises.
content: As delegates inside the COP26 conference hall in Glasgow heard promises of new private-sector funding for climate change, protesters marched in the city on Wednesday in opposition to “greenwashing” — when companies claim to be protecting the environment while continuing to harm it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian M. Rosenthal
title: N.Y.C. Cabbies Win Millions More in Aid After Hunger Strike
description: The announcement was a victory for drivers who stopped eating to protest an earlier bailout plan they said did not go far enough.
content: New York officials said Wednesday they had struck a deal with the largest holder of taxi loans in the city to help rescue thousands of cabbies who have been crushed under paralyzing debt after years of exploitative practices in the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: In a ‘Workers Economy,’ Who Really Holds the Cards?
description: Some people are resigning. Some are sitting on the sidelines awaiting a prime gig. Others are flexing their muscles — requesting raises, or remote options — while still clocking in.
content: Zella Roberts was one of the highest performing waitresses at the Sonic drive-in in Asheville, N.C., her manager told her, but there were days during the pandemic when she questioned whether she could continue her job. The customers were unruly and often unmasked; the base pay was $5 an hour. Then one afternoon, last November, a man coughed in her face as she served him a hot dog. Ms. Roberts went home and cried.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Heart and Soul of a Franchise Shines Through
description: Freddie Freeman might have played his final game for Atlanta on Tuesday. Even if he did, he has already delivered on a promise he made to honor his mother.
content: HOUSTON — The friendliest man in baseball is a champion. Freddie Freeman, the Atlanta Braves’ slugger known for smiles, small talk and soft-serve ice cream, hit the last home run of the season and caught the throw from shortstop for the final out of the World Series. Nice guys finish first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Kate Conger
title: Google Wants to Work With the Pentagon Again, Despite Employee Concerns
description: Three years ago, the company walked away from a Defense Department project after employees objected to it. Now the company is working on a new proposal for the Pentagon.
content: Three years after an employee revolt forced Google to abandon work on a Pentagon program that used artificial intelligence, the company is aggressively pursuing a major contract to provide its technology to the military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: ‘My Name Is Cleo’: Girl, 4, Is Found 18 Days After Vanishing From Campsite
description: Cleo Smith disappeared one night while camping with her family in a remote area of Australia. She was found “alive and well” in a locked house, and a man was detained.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — A 4-year-old girl who vanished in the dead of night while camping with her family in a remote area of Western Australia was found “alive and well” 18 days later in a locked house, the authorities said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: ‘The planet is in serious trouble,’ says Scotland’s leader, Nicola Sturgeon.
description: The leader of the nation hosting COP26 said she hoped that a century from now, people will look back and “describe Glasgow as the place which really took the correct fork in the road for our planet.”
content: GLASGOW — Scotland’s leader, Nicola Sturgeon, said Wednesday that the nation must accelerate its transition away from fossil fuels but that it was imperative to do so in a way that created jobs and new opportunities in renewable energy and carbon alternatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ionova
title: With scant vaccine supplies, the W.H.O. presses Latin America and the Caribbean to hold off on boosters.
description: Sufficient shipments of vaccines have been slow to reach many countries in the region and economic inequalities are complicating matters.
content: Officials from the World Health Organization on Wednesday urged countries in Latin America and the Caribbean to limit administering booster shots and hold off on vaccinating children, allocating scant doses to the most vulnerable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Lawmakers Ask Biden to Rescind Medals for Wounded Knee Massacre
description: Seventeen members of Congress said they believed it was within President Biden’s authority to revoke Medals of Honor “when appropriate.”
content: More than a dozen members of Congress have called on President Biden to use his executive authority to revoke Medals of Honor awarded for the killings of members of the Lakota Sioux tribe, including unarmed women and children, at Wounded Knee, S.D., in the 19th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Satellite monitoring of emissions from countries and companies ‘changes everything,’ Al Gore says.
description: Real-time checks on where greenhouse gases are being produced may prove a powerful weapon in the fight to cool the earth.
content: One of the challenges in holding companies and countries accountable for their roles in global warming is how greenhouse gas emission data has been self-reported, former Vice President Al Gore said Wednesday on the sidelines of the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Making His Marathon Debut, With a Lot of Help From New Friends
description: Ben True needed runners to train with him in New Hampshire, so he recruited some young talent.
content: HANOVER, N.H. — Ben True spent years training alone. A solitary figure on the roads and trails near his home here in Hanover, he logged long miles in pursuit of distance-running glory. It was not that he wanted to be doing everything by himself, without the help of a team. But New Hampshire — far from the running meccas of Boulder, Colo., or Flagstaff, Ariz. — is home for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: House Hunting in Mexico: A Modern Hillside Masterpiece in Acapulco
description: Once a destination for international jet-setters, Acapulco has been plagued by violence in recent years, though it remains popular with Mexican tourists.
content: This contemporary five-bedroom home overlooks Acapulco Bay from within the hillside gated community of Las Brisas in Acapulco, on Mexico’s Pacific Coast. The house was designed by the renowned Mexican architect Miguel Ángel Aragonés and completed last year, said Laura de la Torre de Skipsey, an agent with Mexico Sotheby’s International Realty, which has the listing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barry P. McDonald
title: This Is the Shadiest Part of the Supreme Court
description: Justices have revealed another problem with the court’s “shadow docket.”
content: The Supreme Court has come under increasing scrutiny for its so-called shadow docket: rulings issued on an expedited basis without the full briefing, argumentation and written opinions that cases on its main docket receive. These rulings are often divided along partisan lines, as seen in a recent, and controversial, example: the conservative majority’s rejection of a request in September to pause a Texas abortion law until it could be more fully reviewed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Aaron Rodgers Out After Positive Coronavirus Test
description: The Green Bay Packers quarterback will miss Sunday’s game against Kansas City after testing positive for the virus and raised questions about his vaccination status.
content: Green Bay Packers star quarterback Aaron Rodgers will miss at least Sunday’s game at Kansas City after testing positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin, Alexander Burns and Thomas Kaplan
title: Terry McAuliffe concedes to Glenn Youngkin, a Republican financier, in the Virginia governor’s race.
