description: The Democrat’s defeat in his bid to return to the governor’s office came a year after Joseph R. Biden Jr. carried Virginia by 10 points.
content: Former Gov. Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic candidate for governor in Virginia, conceded on Wednesday morning to his Republican opponent, the businessman Glenn Youngkin, as the Republican Party claimed the state’s governorship for the first time in more than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Gucci Makes a Hollywood Entrance
description: For its first in-person show since February 2020, the Italian brand made movie-adjacent magic. Lots of stars aligned.
content: LOS ANGELES — On election night in much of America, in the shadow of Grauman’s Chinese Theater and amid the panting anticipation for Ridley Scott’s “House of Gucci” film, the actual Gucci designer Alessandro Michele brought the “Gucci Love Parade,” his first in-person show since February 2020, to Hollywood Boulevard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Your Guide to the 2021 New York City Marathon
description: Everything you need to know about the 50th running of the five borough race.
content: After a long, marathon-less year, the New York City Marathon returns in triumphant fashion on Sunday, Nov. 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Aida Rodriguez Wants You to Laugh at the Pain
description: The Dominican American comic hopes to broaden the way Latinos are represented in comedy. She’s finally getting her chance.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — “I didn’t know I was half Dominican until I got older,” the comedian Aida Rodriguez said from the stage at the Stateside Theater. “They broke it to me like it was bad news.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Rough Night for Democrats Exposes the Party’s Weakness
description: Less than a year after taking power in Washington, the party faces a grim immediate future, struggling to energize voters without a presidential foil and losing messaging wars to Republicans.
content: The menacing thunder couldn’t get much louder for Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Buffalo’s race for mayor appears to swing toward the write-in incumbent, Byron Brown.
description: His opponent, India Walton, won the Democratic primary in June. The final count of votes marked “write-in” could take weeks to complete.
content: BUFFALO, N.Y. —Mayor Byron W. Brown of Buffalo, an incumbent four-term Democrat, declared victory on Tuesday night in his write-in campaign to defeat his own party’s official nominee, India Walton. But Ms. Walton, a democratic socialist, refused to concede.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Organizers blame the pandemic as frustrations grow over long waits and other glitches at the climate conference.
description: One veteran of the annual gathering described it as the “poorest planed” to date. A young American activist called it a “hellscape.”
content: Logistical complaints are mounting at the United Nations climate conference in Glasgow, where participants waiting in security lines for more than an hour were abruptly told on Wednesday afternoon that there was no room for them inside the venue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Heller
title: What You Remember About ‘Jesus Christ Superstar’
description: Listening to the album. Singing along at the show. And wearing a loincloth to play the title role. All fresh in our readers’ minds in the 50 years since.
content: Fifty year ago, “Jesus Christ Superstar” landed on Broadway at the Mark Hellinger Theater, and the careers of Andrew Lloyd Webber, Tim Rice and Ben Vereen would never be the same. Responding to a recent article celebrating the anniversary, nearly 400 readers shared their own memories of hearing, seeing or acting in the show, then and since. Here is an edited selection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Why Democrats Are in Trouble
description: The election in Virginia is more than just a reflection on Biden’s failures.
content: Days before it became clear that the Republican Glenn Youngkin would win Virginia’s gubernatorial race, pollsters, pundits and political strategists were trying to explain why a race that was the Democrat Terry McAuliffe’s to lose was on its way to being lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: China Could Have 1,000 Nuclear Warheads by 2030, Pentagon Says
description: Gen. Mark A. Milley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, called Beijing the “No. 1” nation-state military challenger to the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — China is continuing to strengthen its strategic nuclear arsenal and could have 1,000 nuclear warheads by 2030, according to a new Defense Department report released Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Trump in the Spirit Over Trump in the Flesh
description: That was Glenn Youngkin’s approach. Watch other Republicans mimic it.
content: What candidates don’t do can have as much impact on an election as what they do, and Glenn Youngkin’s victory in Virginia was a triumph of omission. It’s no accident that he never beckoned Donald Trump to campaign with him. It’s no fluke that he never appeared in public with Trump, the most popular figure in the Republican Party by far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Cheers, tears, comfort dogs and Disney balloons: Covid shots for children get underway in a Texas hospital.
description: An 8-year-old eager to hang out with friends said, “It didn’t hurt that much, but it kind of hurt.” A sixth-grader getting vaccinated on her birthday enthused, “This is the best day ever!”
content: HOUSTON — Surrounded by anxious and excited parents, the first young children in Texas — and some of the first in the nation — were vaccinated against the coronavirus early on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: For Progressives, Michelle Wu Points to a Way Forward
description: As a Boston mayoral candidate, she had plenty of opportunity to pivot away from her more liberal ideas. She didn’t, and it paid off.
content: BOSTON — For progressives, Tuesday’s elections brought a litany of bad news and one conspicuous bright spot: Michelle Wu, the newly elected mayor of Boston, who took the stage in a scarlet dress, carrying her 4-year-old son on her hip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: What Jerome Powell Didn’t Do: Lay the Groundwork for Higher Rates
description: He said high inflation was mostly a result of pandemic effects like supply network disruptions, a problem he thinks the Fed can’t fix.
content: The real news out of the Federal Reserve on Wednesday was not in what it did, but in what Chair Jerome Powell didn’t do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Perriello
title: Youngkin’s Victory in Virginia Is a Warning. It’s Also a Roadmap.
description: Democrats should take heed.
content: In the first statewide elections since Donald Trump’s defeat, Republicans appear to have won the governor’s race in Virginia, as well as coming closer than expected in New Jersey. While this is surprising — Republicans had not won a statewide race in Virginia in 12 years — Virginia voters have swung against whichever party holds the White House in 10 of the last 11 gubernatorial races. Perhaps reinforcing this penchant for split governance, Democrats appear to have held the historic gains they made four years ago in the House of Delegates, despite running within district lines heavily gerrymandered toward Republican advantage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Stewart
title: Toni Tipton-Martin Writes Her Own Legacy
description: The cookbook author, who will receive the seventh Julia Child Award on Thursday, is using the prize money to start a foundation to support women in food.
content: Toni Tipton-Martin, a cookbook writer and the editor in chief of Cook’s Country, is unveiling details for her foundation, which will now be known as the Toni Tipton-Martin Foundation, to support future generations of women in food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Election losses leave U.S. Democrats reeling.
content: Virginia has a Republican governor for the first time in more than a decade after an election on Tuesday, dimming U.S. Democrats’ hopes for midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: The Critic Elizabeth Hardwick Was Very Tough on Biographies. Now Here’s One of Her.
description: Cathy Curtis’s “A Splendid Intelligence” diligently covers the life of the essayist and critic who has been best known to the writers who revere her.
content: To be a literary biographer is to court the extravagant ridicule of the very people you write about. For all of the salutary services a writer’s biography can offer — the tracing of the life, the contextualizing of the work, the resuscitation of a reputation and the deliverance from neglect — the biographer has been derided as a “post-mortem exploiter” (Henry James) and a “professional burglar” (Janet Malcolm).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: New York Times Adds 455,000 Subscriptions in Third Quarter
description: After moving behind a paywall, Wirecutter added to the company’s revenue stream.
content: The New York Times Company said on Wednesday that it added 455,000 new digital subscriptions in the third quarter, a gain that keeps the publisher on pace to reach its stated goal of 10 million subscriptions by 2025.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
title: Glenn Youngkin, a Republican financier, defeats Terry McAuliffe in the Virginia governor’s race.
description: Mr. Youngkin, a former private equity executive making his first run for office, focused on education and taxes while projecting a suburban-dad image to create distance from former President Trump.
content: McLEAN, Va. — Republicans claimed the governorship of Virginia for the first time in more than a decade on Wednesday, electing the businessman Glenn Youngkin and presenting their party with a formula for how to exploit President Biden’s vulnerabilities and evade the shadow of Donald J. Trump in Democratic-leaning states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Scottie Pippen Takes Aim at Michael Jordan in New Book
description: In a new memoir, Pippen makes a sharp turn from decades of praising his former Chicago Bulls teammate to calling him selfish, hypocritical and insensitive.
content: Scottie Pippen’s new memoir, “Unguarded,” is a master class in settling scores, or creating new ones.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Elections, Afghanistan, Atlanta Braves: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast Mailbag! Halsey, Nicki, TikTok and, of Course, Taylor
description: Answering your questions about pop’s big names, the state of the music video and more.
content: You ask, we answer. Or prevaricate. It depends!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carina Chocano
title: The Strange Effects of Putting an Ordinary Woman Into Glamorous Images
description: Celeste Barber’s Instagram elegantly prompts us to consider why we put so much stock in unrealistic imagery.
content: The woman in one video emerges from a Rolls-Royce wearing nothing but underwear and sunglasses, her arm draped across her bare chest. In another image, a woman in a green bikini and thigh-high patent-leather boots clutches a wall as if suddenly realizing she’s had one too many. A video features a couple of Kardashian-Jenners palpating a wall illuminated by blinking neon tube lights. A woman straddles her open hatchback while wrapped in string.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Inflation Bonds Are Getting a Big Rate Bump
description: The rise in prices has affected not only consumer goods but some government savings bonds, and it could benefit some investors looking for safe spaces for their money.
content: As the country recovers from the pandemic, rising prices have become a worry for many Americans. But inflation has also driven up rates on some government savings bonds, creating an opportunity for people seeking a safe haven for their cash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Katie Glueck
title: N.Y. Democrats Assess Losses to Republicans: ‘This Was a Shellacking’
description: While Eric Adams easily won the New York City mayor’s race, Republicans made inroads across New York, from bedroom communities on Long Island to City Council races in Queens and Brooklyn.
content: New York Democrats were left reeling on Wednesday after startling electoral losses from the tip of Long Island to the shores of Lake Erie, as a re-energized Republican Party showed it could make deep inroads even in one of the country’s liberal strongholds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Tech Can’t Fix the Problem of Cars
description: Flashy new car technology may be exciting, but it might also be distracting us from what we need.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: After Celebrating the U.S. Abroad, Biden Returns to Challenges at Home
description: Republican gains on Election Day come at a vulnerable time for the president’s agenda.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Wednesday returned from his second trip abroad since taking office aiming to celebrate the return of U.S. leadership on the global stage and hoping for Democratic victories in key elections in Virginia and New Jersey. It did not work out like that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Joie de Vivre
description: Dan Harris’s debut contemplates the deep questions.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations and welcome to Dan Harris, who is making his New York Times Crossword debut today!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Damien Cave
title: Australia’s climate pledges fall short, again, critics say.
description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison did not announce any firm plans to move away from the country’s deep investment in fossil fuel production.
content: Australia, a major producer of fossil fuels that has long been criticized for dragging its feet on climate change, has done little this week to change that perception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Danny Hakim
title: He Escaped Prison in 2015. Did He Kill a Young Mother Decades Before?
description: A bid to exonerate two men in a Buffalo-area murder centers on the possible role in the crime of Richard Matt, a notorious New York killer.
content: TONAWANDA, N.Y. — In February 1993, Deborah Meindl walked into her house in this working-class Buffalo suburb on a blustery Wednesday afternoon, and never left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Noah Weiland
title: Biden urges vaccinations for millions of newly eligible children.
description: A vaccination program for children will roll out next week with more doses shipping each day, he said, calling it “a day of relief and celebration.”
content: President Biden on Wednesday urged millions of parents to get their young children vaccinated against the coronavirus, touting the government’s authorization of inoculations for children between 5 and 11 as a major milestone in the nation’s effort to end the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Climate Change Threatens Wine, and a Way of Life, in Jura
description: Extreme weather has ruined grape crops throughout this small French region known for natural wine. “If it continues like this, how will we continue to make Jura wine? I really don’t know,” said one winegrower.
content: On the banks of the Cuisance River in eastern France, scattered between the ancient stone houses of the Arbois commune, small groups of wine enthusiasts sat under the fall sun, sipping on chardonnay and trousseau grown in the foothills of the Jura mountains, one of the smallest but most beloved wine regions in France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Torn From Parents in the Belgian Congo, Women Seek Reparations
description: Belgium has apologized for the kidnapping and deportation of thousands of mixed-race children under its colonial rule. Survivors say that reparations should be the next step.
content: BRUSSELS — The girls were as young as 2, some still breastfeeding, and no older than 4 when they were taken from their mothers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Eric Adams’s victory speech, in full.
description: Here is a transcript of Eric Adams’s remarks after he was elected mayor of New York City.

source.name: The New York Times

title: In Virginia, frustration with schooling during the pandemic played a part in Youngkin’s win.
description: Glenn Youngkin, a Republican, campaigned heavily on education — and in opposition to what he called “critical race theory” — in his successful campaign for Virginia governor against the Democrat Terry McAuliffe. But Mr. Youngkin also made an issue of the state’s handling of schooling during the pandemic, which may have played a part in his win.
content: Glenn Youngkin, a Republican, campaigned heavily on education — and in opposition to what he called “critical race theory” — in his successful campaign for Virginia governor against the Democrat Terry McAuliffe. author: By Somini Sengupta
title: A new $10.5 billion fund aims to spur green energy projects in poor countries.
description: Its backers say it will jump-start investments in clean energy that would not otherwise draw private investors.
content: A group of philanthropic foundations and international development banks on Wednesday announced a $10.5 billion fund to help emerging economies with growing energy needs make the switch from fossil fuels to renewable sources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Thing Everyone Wants but No One Actually Wears
description: World Series rings are the ultimate goal for many in baseball, but for those who win them practicality can get in the way.
content: HOUSTON — Someday you may find yourself in a restaurant, an airport or a store with a member of the 2021 Atlanta Braves. You might remember him from that joyous throng bouncing around on the grass at Minute Maid Park in Houston after winning the World Series. And if you shake his hand, you might notice something missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Ziegler
title: We Can Now See the Playbook for Overturning Roe v. Wade
description: The Supreme Court’s conservatives may have calculated that they need political cover for overturning or badly damaging Roe later this term.
content: After Monday’s Supreme Court oral arguments, the writing seems to be on the wall for Senate Bill 8, the Texas law that bans abortion starting about six weeks after a person’s last menstrual period and that hands enforcement to private citizens. It now looks as though two conservative justices may flip on the Texas law and put it in jeopardy — while clearing the way for the ultimate goal of overturning Roe v. Wade next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Tony Downs, Economist Who Studied Why People Vote, Dies at 90
description: He explored democracy, traffic congestion, race relations and bureaucrats through the prism of an economist.
content: Anthony Downs majored in political theory along with international relations at Carleton College in Northfield, Minn., but by the time he graduated in 1952 the most enduring lesson he had learned about democracy had come from his fellow students rather than his professors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Glenn Youngkin’s Journey From the Heights of Finance to the Top Tier of G.O.P. Politics
description: Helped by his personal fortune, the victor in the Virginia governor’s race won over voters who were put off by Trumpism but were not, it turned out, entirely opposed to elevating another Republican.
content: One year ago, Glenn Youngkin was well known in the world of high finance, but almost a complete cipher in politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Republicans Block a Second Voting Rights Bill in the Senate
description: Democrats hope that a filibuster of a measure named for former Representative John Lewis of Georgia, the civil rights icon, will help build momentum for a change in Senate rules.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Wednesday blocked legislation to restore parts of the landmark Voting Rights Act weakened by Supreme Court rulings, making it the second major voting bill to be derailed by a G.O.P. filibuster in the past two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Michelle Wu is elected mayor of Boston.
description: Ms. Wu is the first woman and the first person of color to be elected mayor in Boston.
content: BOSTON — Michelle Wu, who entered public service out of frustration with the obstacles that her immigrant family faced, will be the next mayor of Boston, pledging to make the city a proving ground for progressive policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Fallon: Biden Can Cut Emissions Just as He Did His Ratings
description: “I mean, he cut his approval rating in half in three months,” Fallon joked on Tuesday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Brazil presents itself as part of the solution, but critics see a climate scofflaw.
description: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil, a global climate leader turned environmental offender under President Jair Bolsonaro, approached the United Nations climate conference in Glasgow ready to prove that it was changing course, with commitments to create green jobs, cut carbon emissions and curb deforestation.
